title: How to Make a Jewelry Tree

steps.headline: Choose your vase.
steps.description: Find a vase online, a thrift store, or home and garden retailer. The opening should be narrow to support your branches. The height will also play a factor in which branches you will be using. Choose a colour that compliments the palette of your room or that will highlight your jewelry.

steps.headline: Gather your branches.
steps.description: Bring your vase along with you as you gather branches outdoors. You want sturdy branches that are long enough to have at least half of their length in your vase. Find branches with character and that are preferably dry. You may also branches branches at an art supply store.

steps.headline: Paint your branches.
steps.description: Use florist shears or scissors to cut off any twigs or unsightly imperfections. Use spray paint to give your branches a nice sheen. For example, silver spray paint can give your display a nice metallic look that will make your jewelry pop. You may always change your display by painting new branches a different colour or changing your vase completely.

steps.headline: Insert your branches into the vase.
steps.description: Arrange your branches into a display that suits your room. You may find that you need to dispose of extra branches if it seems unsightly with jewelry added.

steps.headline: Hang your jewelry.
steps.description: Create a fun display by hanging necklaces, bracelets, and earrings on the branches. Make sure that there is enough support for your heavier pieces. Organizing your pieces by colour or design can create different effects.

steps.headline: Gather your branches.
steps.description: Depending on your location and time of year, it may be difficult to find perfect branches and twigs. Ideally, you want them to be dry and easily accessible. Dead branches and twigs are easier to work with because they are more flexible. Choose a strong thick piece to use as the trunk of the jewelry tree and a thicker log for your base. Choose your twigs and branches that have character. It's okay if there are slight imperfections because you can shape your trunk and branches later.

steps.headline: Cut your base.
steps.description: Use a miter saw or handsaw to cut a 1.5 inch disk from your log. The disk will support your trunk and act as base for stability as you place your jewelry.

steps.headline: Cut the trunk of your tree.
steps.description: Use a handsaw or limb pruner to cut your trunk to your desired height. You want a trunk that's about 22 inches tall for a thick base. Cut off any unsightly imperfections and trim down any extra branches on your trunk.

steps.headline: Drill a hole on your base.
steps.description: Using a drill bit that is the same diameter as your trunk, drill a hole about ⅔ of the way into the disk. Use a spade bit to drill a hole about the same width of the branch that you are using as the trunk of your jewelry tree. The spade bit should have slightly poked through the bottom of the base but make sure that the rest of the bit does not. Test that the trunk fits fare enough into the base that it is stable. Continue drilling carefully if it still needs more room.

steps.headline: Drill a hole in the bottom of the trunk.
steps.description: Insert the trunk into the base disk and turn it upside down. You should see the hole in which the tip of your spade bit came through. Use a small drill bit, slightly smaller than 2 inches, to drill a hole through the bottom of the disk and into the bottom of the trunk, about ½ - ¾ inches. Make sure to keep the trunk inserted in the base until you are finished drilling.

steps.headline: Create a countersink hole in your bamboo bowl.
steps.description: Turn your bamboo bowl upside down and drill through the center with the same drill bit you used to drill the hole in your trunk, slightly smaller than two inches. Create a countersink hole large enough for the head of the screw by using a slightly larger drill bit to drill into the bowl but not deep enough that you drill through it. Use tape to mark off how deep you want to drill your countersink hole.

steps.headline: Glue the trunk branch into the base.
steps.description: Use a dollop of Gorilla glue to glue the trunk branch into the disk base. Only use enough glue to fit neatly into the large hole of the disk base. Allow the glue to sit for an hour and harden.

steps.headline: Glue the base into the bowl.
steps.description: Once the branch has been securely glued into the base disk, turn it over and place some Gorilla Glue at the center and around the edges of the base disk and set it at the bottom of the bamboo bowl.

steps.headline: Screw the base into the bowl.
steps.description: Insert your two inch wood screw at the bottom of the bowl and thread it through the disk base and the trunk branch using hole that you drilled earlier. Secure the branch as you gently tighten the screw snugly inside the countersink hole.

steps.headline: Add new branches.
steps.description: Let the trunk's natural shape dictate where your should attach your branches and what directions they should sprout. Choose branches that are sturdy and that have character. Match drill bits with the width of the new branches and drill holes into the trunk. Drop a bit of Gorilla Glue into the holes and add your branches. You may also attach your new branches using twine for are more artful look. Cut a long piece of twine and secure your new branches onto the trunk. Wrap each branch tightly but make sure to switch directions to secure the branches. Tie a knot at the end of the twine and Gorilla glue the end of the twine neatly.

steps.headline: Allow the branches to dry.
steps.description: Keep the branches in place with other loose branches or scraps as the glue dries. Make sure to check on your grafted branches as the glue dries so that they don't shift or fall.

steps.headline: Clean off your jewelry tree and add jewelry.
steps.description: Clean off any bits of dirt or debris once the glue has dried. Store larger pieces of jewelry, like bracelets or bangles, in the bamboo bowl. Display necklaces and earings on the trunk and  grafted branches.

steps.headline: Design your tree.
steps.description: Research online and download a template or create your own. You may use a design program like Adobe Illustrator to enlarge your design. Print your design on stencil decal vinyl either using a Cricut vinyl plotter or Graphtect Vinyl plotter. If you do not have these tools, you may also simply print out your design on paper.

steps.headline: Trace your design.
steps.description: Clean your metal with a rag and solvent to remove any grease or debris. Whether using stencil decal vinyl or paper, place your design on your 16 gauge metal. Use a soapstone pencil or a sharpie marker to trace your design onto the metal.

steps.headline: Cut out your design.
steps.description: Use a plasma cutter and keep the tip around ⅛ of an inch from the metal. Be careful to create a nice clean and smooth cut. Make sure the work area is well lit and well ventilated. Wear the proper safety gear including goggles, gloves, and protective eye gear. If you are using a normal 110v outlet, you may use a Hobart 250ci Plasma Cutter.

steps.headline: Grind out the edges.
steps.description: Slag will be produced on the bottom and top of the metal when using the plasma cutter. Use your angle grinder to remove any slag. Clamp down your tree and use a 60 to 80 grit flap disc to clean the edges. Use the 80 grit flap disc to create the illusion of bark by grinding the surface of the tree. Remove blotches of film from the metal with the grinder for a bark like look.

steps.headline: Drill holes.
steps.description: Using a ¼ inch drill bit on the leaves, create holes so that you are able to dangle earings. You may experiment with slightly larger drill bits to hang special bracelets..

steps.headline: Stand your tree up.
steps.description: Bend your tree using a pry bar or a chisel so that it is able to stand vertically. Create a flap at the bottom of the trunk by clamping down your tree to your workbench and allowing a bit of the trunk to hang over your table. Then use the chisel or pry bar to bend the overhang towards the ground.

steps.headline: Cut the base.
steps.description: Use the plasma cutter to cut a 6 x 4 inch shape from your 10 gauge steel. Create a heavy base. The shape you choose is completely to your preference.

steps.headline: Attach your base.
steps.description: Use a clear quick setting epoxy on the flap of your tree to attach it to the base. Clamp the base of your tree down to the base for an hour or two to let the glue dry.

steps.headline: Adjust to your preference.
steps.description: Create dimension and character by bending leaves and branches. Clamp your tree down and use a chisel or pry bar to bend your leaves. When done shaping your piece, use a few thin coats of solvent based metal sealer to seal the entire jewelry tree. Purchase solvent based metal sealer at your local hardware store.

steps.headline: Hang your jewelry.
steps.description: Avoid scratching surfaces by adding some felt pads to the bottom of your piece. Add earrings, necklaces, and other jewelry to your finished tree.

tyn: Freshly cut log (preferably hard wood tree)
Angle Grinder (Flap Disc and Metal Cutoff Blade)

Bring your vase along with you as you gather branches outdoors. You want sturdy branches that are long enough to have at least half of their length in your vase. Use florist shears or scissors to cut off any twigs or unsightly imperfections. Use spray paint to give your branches a nice sheen. You may also attach your new branches using twine for are more artful look. Cut a long piece of twine and secure your new branches onto the trunk. Whether using stencil decal vinyl or paper, place your design on your 16 gauge metal. Use a soapstone pencil or a sharpie marker to trace your design onto the metal. Cut out your design. Use a plasma cutter and keep the tip around ⅛ of an inch from the metal. Be careful to create a nice clean and smooth cut. Make sure the work area is well lit and well ventilated. Wear the proper safety gear including goggles, gloves, and protective eye gear. If you are using a normal 110v outlet, you may use a Hobart 250ci Plasma Cutter. Grind out the edges. Slag will be produced on the bottom and top of the metal when using the plasma cutter. Use your angle grinder to remove any slag. Clamp down your tree and use a 60 to 80 grit flap disc to clean the edges. Use the 80 grit flap disc to create the illusion of bark by grinding the surface of the tree. Remove blotches of film from the metal with the grinder for a bark like look. Drill holes. Using a ¼ inch drill bit on the leaves, create holes so that you are able to dangle earings. Purchase solvent based metal sealer at your local hardware store. Hang your jewelry. Avoid scratching surfaces by adding some felt pads to the bottom of your piece. Add earrings, necklaces, and other jewelry to your finished tree.
sentences: Using a Vase Choose your vase.
Find a vase online, a thrift store, or home and garden retailer.
The opening should be narrow to support your branches.
The height will also play a factor in which branches you will be using.
Choose a colour that compliments the palette of your room or that will highlight your jewelry.
Gather your branches.
Bring your vase along with you as you gather branches outdoors.
You want sturdy branches that are long enough to have at least half of their length in your vase.
Find branches with character and that are preferably dry.
You may also branches branches at an art supply store.
Paint your branches.
Use florist shears or scissors to cut off any twigs or unsightly imperfections.
Use spray paint to give your branches a nice sheen.
For example, silver spray paint can give your display a nice metallic look that will make your jewelry pop.
You may always change your display by painting new branches a different colour or changing your vase completely.
Insert your branches into the vase.
Arrange your branches into a display that suits your room.
You may find that you need to dispose of extra branches if it seems unsightly with jewelry added.
Hang your jewelry.
Create a fun display by hanging necklaces, bracelets, and earrings on the branches.
Make sure that there is enough support for your heavier pieces.
Organizing your pieces by colour or design can create different effects.
Using Wood and Branches Gather your branches.
Depending on your location and time of year, it may be difficult to find perfect branches and twigs.
Ideally, you want them to be dry and easily accessible.
Dead branches and twigs are easier to work with because they are more flexible.
Choose a strong thick piece to use as the trunk of the jewelry tree and a thicker log for your base.
Choose your twigs and branches that have character.
It's okay if there are slight imperfections because you can shape your trunk and branches later.
Cut your base.
Use a miter saw or handsaw to cut a 1.5 inch disk from your log.
The disk will support your trunk and act as base for stability as you place your jewelry.
Cut the trunk of your tree.
Use a handsaw or limb pruner to cut your trunk to your desired height.
You want a trunk that's about 22 inches tall for a thick base.
Cut off any unsightly imperfections and trim down any extra branches on your trunk.
Drill a hole on your base.
Using a drill bit that is the same diameter as your trunk, drill a hole about ⅔ of the way into the disk.
Use a spade bit to drill a hole about the same width of the branch that you are using as the trunk of your jewelry tree.
The spade bit should have slightly poked through the bottom of the base but make sure that the rest of the bit does not.
Test that the trunk fits fare enough into the base that it is stable.
Continue drilling carefully if it still needs more room.
Drill a hole in the bottom of the trunk.
Insert the trunk into the base disk and turn it upside down.
You should see the hole in which the tip of your spade bit came through.
Use a small drill bit, slightly smaller than 2 inches, to drill a hole through the bottom of the disk and into the bottom of the trunk, about ½ - ¾ inches.
Make sure to keep the trunk inserted in the base until you are finished drilling.
Create a countersink hole in your bamboo bowl.
Turn your bamboo bowl upside down and drill through the center with the same drill bit you used to drill the hole in your trunk, slightly smaller than two inches.
Create a countersink hole large enough for the head of the screw by using a slightly larger drill bit to drill into the bowl but not deep enough that you drill through it.
Use tape to mark off how deep you want to drill your countersink hole.
Glue the trunk branch into the base.
Use a dollop of Gorilla glue to glue the trunk branch into the disk base.
Only use enough glue to fit neatly into the large hole of the disk base.
Allow the glue to sit for an hour and harden.
Glue the base into the bowl.
Once the branch has been securely glued into the base disk, turn it over and place some Gorilla Glue at the center and around the edges of the base disk and set it at the bottom of the bamboo bowl.
Screw the base into the bowl.
Insert your two inch wood screw at the bottom of the bowl and thread it through the disk base and the trunk branch using hole that you drilled earlier.
Secure the branch as you gently tighten the screw snugly inside the countersink hole.
Add new branches.
Let the trunk's natural shape dictate where your should attach your branches and what directions they should sprout.
Choose branches that are sturdy and that have character.
Match drill bits with the width of the new branches and drill holes into the trunk.
Drop a bit of Gorilla Glue into the holes and add your branches.
You may also attach your new branches using twine for are more artful look.
Cut a long piece of twine and secure your new branches onto the trunk.
Wrap each branch tightly but make sure to switch directions to secure the branches.
Tie a knot at the end of the twine and Gorilla glue the end of the twine neatly.
Allow the branches to dry.
Keep the branches in place with other loose branches or scraps as the glue dries.
Make sure to check on your grafted branches as the glue dries so that they don't shift or fall.
Clean off your jewelry tree and add jewelry.
Clean off any bits of dirt or debris once the glue has dried.
Store larger pieces of jewelry, like bracelets or bangles, in the bamboo bowl.
Display necklaces and earings on the trunk and  grafted branches.
Creating a Metal Jewelry Tree Design your tree.
Research online and download a template or create your own.
You may use a design program like Adobe Illustrator to enlarge your design.
Print your design on stencil decal vinyl either using a Cricut vinyl plotter or Graphtect Vinyl plotter.
If you do not have these tools, you may also simply print out your design on paper.
Trace your design.
Clean your metal with a rag and solvent to remove any grease or debris.
Whether using stencil decal vinyl or paper, place your design on your 16 gauge metal.
Use a soapstone pencil or a sharpie marker to trace your design onto the metal.
Cut out your design.
Use a plasma cutter and keep the tip around ⅛ of an inch from the metal.
Be careful to create a nice clean and smooth cut.
Make sure the work area is well lit and well ventilated.
Wear the proper safety gear including goggles, gloves, and protective eye gear.
If you are using a normal 110v outlet, you may use a Hobart 250ci Plasma Cutter.
Grind out the edges.
Slag will be produced on the bottom and top of the metal when using the plasma cutter.
Use your angle grinder to remove any slag.
Clamp down your tree and use a 60 to 80 grit flap disc to clean the edges.
Use the 80 grit flap disc to create the illusion of bark by grinding the surface of the tree.
Remove blotches of film from the metal with the grinder for a bark like look.
Drill holes.
Using a ¼ inch drill bit on the leaves, create holes so that you are able to dangle earings.
You may experiment with slightly larger drill bits to hang special bracelets..
Stand your tree up.
Bend your tree using a pry bar or a chisel so that it is able to stand vertically.
Create a flap at the bottom of the trunk by clamping down your tree to your workbench and allowing a bit of the trunk to hang over your table.
Then use the chisel or pry bar to bend the overhang towards the ground.
Cut the base.
Use the plasma cutter to cut a 6 x 4 inch shape from your 10 gauge steel.
Create a heavy base.
The shape you choose is completely to your preference.
Attach your base.
Use a clear quick setting epoxy on the flap of your tree to attach it to the base.
Clamp the base of your tree down to the base for an hour or two to let the glue dry.
Adjust to your preference.
Create dimension and character by bending leaves and branches.
Clamp your tree down and use a chisel or pry bar to bend your leaves.
When done shaping your piece, use a few thin coats of solvent based metal sealer to seal the entire jewelry tree.
Purchase solvent based metal sealer at your local hardware store.
Hang your jewelry.
Avoid scratching surfaces by adding some felt pads to the bottom of your piece.
Add earrings, necklaces, and other jewelry to your finished tree.
